synonyms: policy for responding to climate change

related.prefLabel: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change

narrower.prefLabel: cooperation in the field of education

synonyms: further development of the European Union

related.prefLabel: cooperation in the field of education
Publications Office of the European Union

definition: Aa composition of systems, institutions, procedures, social relations or infrastructures whereby parties sell and buy agricultural products.
Concept referring to the set of legislation and practices adopted by the European Union to provide a common, unified policy on agriculture.

Applicable since 1 August 2017, the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme combines two previous schemes (the school fruit and vegetables scheme and the school milk scheme) under a single legal framework for more efficiency and an enhanced focus on health and educational. The scheme supports the distribution of products, educational measures and information measures.

Payments under the common agricultural policy granted directly to farmers in the form of a basic income support, decoupled from production and stabilising their income stemming from sales on the markets, which are subject to volatility.

Biocidal products are used to control unwanted organisms that are harmful to human or animal health or to the environment, or that cause damage to human activities. These harmful organisms include pests (e.g. insects, rats or mice) and microorganisms (e.g. bacteria, viruses, mould).

Plant variety rights (also called plant breeders’ rights) are a form of intellectual property right designed specifically to protect new varieties of plants. These rights offer legal protection as a reward for the investment plant breeders make in breeding and developing new varieties.
Farming processes which minimise the amount of emissions caused by the activity.
Food grown or developed for livestock and poultry.

Consists of plants that produce a pod with seeds inside. The term legume is used to describe the seeds of these plants. Common edible legumes include lentils, peas, chickpeas, beans, soybeans, and peanuts.
A crop that provides a raw material for use in industry.
A twining climbing plant native to north temperate regions, cultivated for the flowers borne by the female plant, which are used in brewing beer.
The fiber of the cannabis plant, extracted from the stem and used to make rope, strong fabrics, fiberboard, and paper.
A plant grown to produce biofuels, or directly exploited for its energy content.
A sweet crystalline substance obtained from various plants, especially sugar cane and sugar beet, consisting essentially of sucrose, and used as a sweetener in food and drink.
Animal by-products (ABPs) are materials of animal origin that people do not consume.

A colorless volatile flammable liquid that is produced by the natural fermentation of sugars and is the intoxicating constituent of wine, beer, spirits, and other drinks, and is also used as an industrial solvent and as fuel.
Aromatised wine products are alcoholic beverages produced by adding flavourings to certain wine products as well as other ingredients, such as grape must and/or alcohol, colours and sugars.
Spirit drinks are alcoholic drinks produced through the process of distillation.
Any plant of the grass family yielding an edible grain, as wheat, rye, oats, rice, or corn.

Protein crops are crops that provide substantial protein, a large class of naturally occurring complex combinations of amino acids. Such crops, including various oilseeds and grains, are important in meeting the nutrient requirements of farm animals. The main protein crops grown in the EU are field peas, broad and field beans and lupines.

Oilseeds are generally, seeds grown primarily for the production of edible (i.e. cooking) oils.  Oilseeds are used for food, feed, fuel and industrial purposes. Crushing the oilseeds provides vegetables oils and meal. Vegetable oil is generally used in the food industry or to produce biodiesel, while oilseed meals are an important component of animal feed.
Bio-based products are wholly or partly derived from materials of biological origin, excluding materials embedded in geological formations and/or fossilised.
Socioeconomic use of land (e.g. agriculture, forestry, recreation or residential use).

Agrifood tech includes all components as food travels from the farm to the fork, including agriculture, manufacturing, food processing, non-food processing, wholesale and logistics, foodservices, food discovery, food regulation, R&D, and financial services. Agrifood therefore essentially combines two (often regarded separate) industries: agriculture-tech (agtech) and food technology.
The study of the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services related to food.
Agreements which prevent, restrict or distort competition between private enterprises.
Misleading representation of goods or services conveyed through false or fraudulent claims or statements.
A group of businesses that team up or form a monopoly in order to dictate pricing in a particular market.
State aid is an advantage given by a government that may provide a company with an unfair competitive edge over its commercial rivals.
Deregulation is the reduction or elimination of government power over a particular industry, usually enacted to try to boost economic growth.
Antitrust laws promote and protect healthy competition within all sectors of the economy by limiting the market power of any particular firm.
International competition is when companies compete to sell goods and services on an international scale.

International organisations are entities established by formal political agreements between their members that have the status of international treaties; their existence is recognised by law in their member countries; they are not treated as resident institutional units of the countries in which they are located.

synonyms: United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation
Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
General Assembly of the United Nations

definition: Pan-African organisation which replaced the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) on 9 July 2002.
Diplomatic protection is where the home state intervenes on behalf of its nationals who suffer a violation of international law by the host state.
A broad term for legally binding arrangements covered by international law between or among countries.

narrower.prefLabel: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change

prefLabel: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change
synonyms: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

broaderPrefLabel: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change

definition: An organisation formed for the purpose of pooling investors' funds to invest in a range of securities.
Provision of equity capital by financial investors to non-quoted companies with high growth potential.
Directive 2011/61/EU on Alternative Investment Fund Managers
The digital finance strategy sets out general lines on how Europe can support the digital transformation of finance, while regulating its risks.

Used to describe new technology that seeks to improve and automate the delivery and use of financial services. ​​​At its core, fintech is utilized to help companies, business owners and consumers better manage their financial operations, processes, and lives by utilizing specialized software and algorithms that are used on computers and, increasingly, smartphones. Fintech, the word, is a combination of "financial technology".
Policies on acquisition, control, limitations and development of military weaponry.

A coordinated mixture of measures (i.e. diplomatic, military, economic, technological) used by state or non-state actors to exploit vulnerabilities of the EU while remaining below the threshold of formal warfare.

An EU strategy covering the period from 2020 to 2025 focusing on priority areas where the EU can help Member States in fostering security with tools and measures ensuring security in physical and digital environments.
An official agreement between two sides who were involved in a conflict.
Intervention in another country by national and/or international actors to establish, reform and strengthen state institutions where these have been seriously eroded or are absent.

International conflict is the result of behaviour designed to destroy, injure, thwart or otherwise control another country or group of countries or their policies. It derives from the incompatibility of goals of at least two nations or groups of nations.

Warfare that is between opposing forces which differ greatly in military power and that typically involves the use of unconventional weapons and tactics (such as those associated with guerrilla warfare and terrorist attacks).

The offensive and defensive use of information and information systems to deny, exploit, corrupt or destroy an adversary’s information, information-based processes, information systems and computer-based networks while protecting one’s own.

synonyms: law on the prevention of war

definition: A set of rules that seeks to limit the effects of armed conflict on civilians. This law defines the right to receive humanitarian assistance, protection of civilians including medical and humanitarian workers, and the protection rights of refugees, prisoners and the wounded and sick.

On 24 February 2022, Russia began a military invasion of Ukraine, in a major escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian conflict that began in 2014. It became the largest military conflict in Europe since World War II.
Threatened or actual imposition of economic costs on one state by another with the objective of extracting a policy concession.
Financial resources from the EU’s budget in the form of grants that cover priorities as defined by the EU and aimed at contributing to the implementation of EU policies.

European Union measures of financial support provided on a complementary basis from the budget in order to address one or more specific policy objectives of the Union. Such instruments may take the form of equity or quasi-equity investments, loans or guarantees, or other risk-sharing instruments, and may, where appropriate, be combined with grants.
synonyms: financial instrument of the European Union

definition: A sum of money or other resources whose principal or interest is set apart for a specific objective in the EU budget.
Financial assistance mechanisms that support EU Member States in financial difficulties.
A programme to assist non-EU countries covered by the European neighbourhood policy that have an International Monetary Fund programme.
The EU is empowered by the EU Treaty to adopt borrowing programmes to mobilise the financial resources necessary to fulfill its mandate.
A temporary recovery instrument allowing the European Commission to raise funds to help repair the immediate economic and social damage brought about by the coronavirus pandemic.
The centrepiece of NextGenerationEU with loans and grants available to support reforms and investments undertaken by EU countries.
Collaboration between the EU and other institutions, member states or third countries in financing programmes of interest to all parties.
Conditions for dispersing EU finances.
Refers to comprehensive, consistent and accessible information on public finances.

synonyms: financing of the European Union budget
financing of the European Union's budget
financing of the budget of the European Union

definition: The financial contribution each member  state makes to the EU's budget.
EU long-term spending plan that lays down the maximum annual amounts (‘ceilings’) which the EU may spend in different political fields (‘headings’) over a period of at least 5 years.
Procedures, policies, and means that help monitor and control the direction, allocation, and usage of financial resources.
Management is the coordination and administration of tasks to achieve a goal.
The act of organizing people to accomplish the desired goals and objectives of a business.

The accounts of a company are published to give greater publicity to the company and to enable the members, investors and public at large to understand the profitability and financial positions of the concern.
Logistics refers to the overall process of managing how resources are acquired, stored, and transported to their final destination.
Project management involves the planning and organizing of an organisation's resources to move a specific task, event, or duty toward completion.
Discipline incorporating managerial, organisational and technical facilities to assist in managing the return to normal life in the case of a major incident as quickly and swiftly as possible.
Ability of an organisation to continue to function even after a disastrous event.
The action or business of promoting and selling products or services, including market research and advertising.
EU quality policy aims to protect the names of specific products to promote their unique characteristics, linked to their geographical origin as well as traditional know-how.

Protected designation of origin (PDO) identifies products that are produced, processed and prepared in a specific geographical area, using the recognized know-how of local producers and ingredients from the region concerned.
The techniques and practices used to bring products, services, opinions, or causes to public notice for the purpose of persuading the public to respond in a certain way toward what is advertised.

A label of environmental excellence that is awarded to products and services meeting high environmental standards throughout their life-cycle: from raw material extraction, to production, distribution and disposal.
Compliance with rules for products to enter the EU market.

Labelling is a part of branding and enables product identification. It is a printed information that is bonded to the product for recognition and provides detailed information about the product.  Labels must comply with the legal obligations.
Market research is the process of determining the viability of a new service or product through research conducted directly with potential customers.
Small and mid-size enterprises (SMEs) are businesses that have revenues, assets, or a number of employees below a certain threshold.

Competence of an organization or country to produce and sell products/services that meet the quality of the markets at the same or lower prices and maximize returns on the resources consumed in producing them.
A startup, or start-up, is a young company with a business model that supports innovation.

A branch of accounting that is concerned with the identification, measurement, analysis, and interpretation of accounting information so that it can be used to help managers make informed operational decisions.
The evaluation of cost data for the purpose of arriving at estimates of costs to be incurred, prices to be paid, costs to be reimbursed, or costs actually incurred.

An independent assessment, resulting in a 'reasonable assurance' opinion, of whether an entity’s reported financial condition, results and use of resources are presented fairly in accordance with the financial reporting framework.
Compliance audit deals with the degree to which the audited entity follows rules, laws and regulation, policies, established codes or agreed terms and conditions, etc.
Any method by which an invoice is electronically presented to a customer for payment.
A readiness to embark on new social or business ventures.

A multinational enterprise, abbreviated as MNE and sometimes also called multinational corporation (MNC), just multinational or international corporation, is an enterprise producing goods or delivering services in more than one country.
The part of the economy owned and controlled by individuals and businesses rather than the government
Method or means by which a company tries to capture value from its business.
Activities that a firm undertakes to create and increase the value of a product, from receipt of raw materials to post-sales support.
Flow of goods and services from the storage of raw materials to finished goods.
A process consisting of separation of CO2 from industrial and energy-related sources, transport to a storage location, and long-term isolation from the atmosphere.
Material that is in the state of burning that produces flames that send out heat and light, and might produce smoke.
An unplanned, unwanted, uncontrolled fire in an area of combustible vegetation starting in rural areas.

Pollution caused by nitrates and organic nitrogen compounds from fertilizer and manure applied in agriculture entering groundwater through leaching and reaching surface water through runoff from agricultural fields.

The decrease of food in subsequent stages of the food supply chain intended for human consumption. The decrease may be accidental or intentional, but ultimately leads to less food being available for all. Food that gets spilled or spoilt before it reaches its final product or retail stage is called food loss.
Extreme weather is a weather event such as snow, rain, drought, flood, or storm that is rare for the place where it occurs.
A heatwave is an extended period of hot weather relative to the expected conditions of the area at that time of year, which may be accompanied by high humidity.
Policies and measures to decrease the vulnerability of natural and human systems against actual or expected climate change effects.

A market-based mechanism under the Kyoto Protocol that allows countries reducing greenhouse gas emissions below what is required to use or trade the excess reductions to offset emissions at another source inside or outside the country.
Achieving net zero carbon dioxide emissions by balancing carbon emissions with carbon removal.
Commitment to specific actions or policies which are not legally binding.
Commitment to specific actions or policies which are legally binding (e.g. Renewable Energy Directive).

Greenwashing is the process of conveying a false impression or providing misleading information about how a company's products are more environmentally sound. Greenwashing is considered an unsubstantiated claim to deceive consumers into believing that a company's products are environmentally friendly.

An EU strategy to support infrastructure development around the world mobilizing funding between 2021-2027 for connectivity projects, notably in the digital, climate and energy, transport, health, education and research sectors.

Regional cooperation between neighboring countries refers to a wide variety of forms of collaboration, ranging from informal cooperation, setting up joint projects (e.g. to build common infrastructure), coordinating policies and regulatory frameworks, to shaping joint policies and institutions.
A country that is not a member of the European Union as well as a country or territory whose citizens do not enjoy the European Union right to free movement.
The sum of ways the EU delivers humanitarian assistance and international aid.

Policy with the aim of minimising contradictions and building synergies between different EU policies to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation, to the benefit of the EU's partner countries.
A fragile region or state has weak capacity to carry out basic governance functions, and lacks the ability to develop mutually constructive relations with society.

Refers to all programmes where cash transfers or vouchers for goods or services are provided directly to aid recipients.  The term is used only to refer to cash transfers or vouchers given to individuals, households or communities, not to governments or to other state actors. This excludes remittances and microfinance in humanitarian interventions.
The use of aircraft, ships, specialised rescue teams and equipment to search for people in distress or imminent danger and to bring them to safety.

Persons or groups of persons who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence, in particular as a result of or in order to avoid the effects of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, violations of human rights or natural or human-made disasters, and who have not crossed an internationally recognized State border.
Humanitarian aid to local communities.

prefLabel: cooperation in the field of education

definition: Objective financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) that supports cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation programmes.

Cooperation between NUTS III regions from at least two different Member States lying directly on the borders or adjacent to them. The policy aims to tackle common challenges identified jointly in the border regions and to exploit the untapped growth potential in border areas, while enhancing the cooperation process for the purposes of the overall harmonious development of the Union.

narrower.prefLabel: Conference on the Future of Europe

definition: The European Movement International is a lobbying association that coordinates the efforts of associations and national councils with the goal of promoting European integration, and disseminating information about it.
An initiative of European institutions, with the objective of bringing Europe closer to the people by engaging with citizens as directly as possible, both online and in person.
prefLabel: Conference on the Future of Europe

definition: A field of study that focuses on current developments in European integration.
How European Union policy affects national policy and vice versa.

The State of the Union address, also known as the State of the European Union or SOTEU, is the annual speech addressed by the President of the European Commission to the European Parliament plenary session in September.

Refers to the EU as one territory without any internal borders or other regulatory obstacles to the free movement of goods and services as defined by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
An area where people and businesses can freely access and exercise online activities under conditions of fair competition, regardless of their nationality or where they live.
Evolving European standards of democracy and activities to promote democratic engagement of citizens at the European level.
synonyms: social dimension of the internal market
Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union
EU Strategy for jobs and growth
EU strategy for jobs and smart
growth strategy of the European Union

definition: Measures and plans in support Europe's recovery from the coronavirus crisis and its consequences.
Support provided by the European Union for cultural and sporting events in order to promote its image.
synonyms: EC participation in a cultural event
EC participation in a sporting event

definition: EU policy with the aim to foster coordinated and coherent decision-making to maximise the sustainable development, economic growth and social cohesion of Member States, in particular with regard to coastal, insular and outermost regions in the Union, as well as maritime sectors.
Digital representation of value, not issued by a central bank, credit institution or e-money institution, which in some circumstances can be used as an alternative to money.

The free movement of capital was introduced as a Treaty freedom by the Maastricht Treaty in 1994. It removed restrictions on capital movements and payments both between EU member states and with third countries.

This term has two meanings. In some cases, it refers to the set of instruments, banking procedures and interbank funds transfer systems which facilitate the circulation of money in a country or in a currency area. In most cases the expression is used as a synonym of ‘funds transfer system’.

The condition in which the financial system — comprising financial intermediaries, markets and market infrastructures — is capable of withstanding shocks and the unravelling of financial imbalances, thereby mitigating the likelihood of disruptions in the financial intermediation process which are severe enough to significantly impair the allocation of savings to profitable investment opportunities.
The risk that an organisation will not be able to meet its monetary commitments, notably any debt-related payments.
EU action plan aimed at mobilising capital for supporting Europe’s businesses.
A subset of a private equity that refers to equity investments made for the launch, early development (seed and start-up), or expansion of a business.
Technical expertise provided to EU Member States to design and implement reforms in a wide range of policy areas.
Regions with a land border, or those regions where more than half of the population lives within 25 km of such a border.
Island regions are defined as NUTS level 3 regions within the European Union (EU) that are entirely composed of one or more islands.
Purchasing power is the value of a currency expressed in terms of the number of goods or services that one unit of money can buy.
Movement towards a less connected world, characterized by powerful nation states, local solutions, and border controls, rather than global institutions, treaties, and free movement.

A 6-month cycle of EU-wide economic policy coordination conducted by the European Commission, which reviews the budget and structural policies of the EU Member States and offers each a set of specific recommendations.
synonyms: European Semester for economic policy coordination

definition: A system of institutions and procedures established with a view to achieving Union objectives in the economic field, more specifically the coordination of economic policies to promote economic and social progress for the EU and its citizens.
synonyms: economic governance of the European Union
fiscal governance of the European Union

definition: EU-level banking supervision and resolution system that consists of an integrated financial framework with a single rulebook, a single supervisory mechanism, common deposit protection and a single bank resolution mechanism.
Economy of the voluntary sector covering cooperatives, associations, mutual benefit societies and foundations.

A social enterprise is broadly defined as an enterprise that puts social benefit above or at least alongside profit. Traditionally these were non-profit organisations or charities with a philanthropic purpose, but they can also be structured as for-profit entities where profit is not the only overriding concern.
Model of economy which minimises waste through reusing, repairing, refurbishing and recycling existing materials and products.

Economic system where activities and services are facilitated by collaborative online platforms that create an open marketplace for the temporary usage of goods or services often provided by private individuals.
Economic system that results in improved human well-being and social equity, while significantly reducing environmental risks and ecological scarcities.
All economic activities related to oceans, seas and coastal areas.
The whole body of salt water that covers nearly three fourths of the surface of the earth.
A portion of the ocean that is partly surrounded by land.
A watercourse is a stream or river, or the channel that it flows along.

Comprises all sectoral and cross-sectoral economic activities generating economic value based on natural capital and non-market goods and services through the conservation of marine habitats and ecosystem services related to the oceans, seas and coasts.
From a broad economic perspective, the bioeconomy refers to the set of economic activities relating to the invention, development, production and use of biological products and processes.
Increase in the general price level of goods and services in an economy over a period of time.
The basic cost of the food, clothing, shelter, and fuel necessary to maintain life. Not to be confused with "Standard of living".

A significant decline in economic activity that lasts for months or even years. Experts declare a recession when a nation’s economy experiences negative gross domestic product (GDP), rising levels of unemployment, falling retail sales, and contracting measures of income and manufacturing for an extended period of time.
A specific amount of money offered to qualified students who are attending post-secondary education programs.
Educational guidance is a process of assisting the individual student to reach optimum educational development.
Teaching, learning or research materials that are in the public domain or released with an intellectual property licence that allows for free use, adaptation and distribution.
Education of EU and non-EU citizens in countries where they are not otherwise nationals.
Assessment is the systematic basis for making inferences about the learning and development of students.
Skills all individuals need for personal fulfilment, active citizenship, social cohesion and employability through lifelong learning in a knowledge society.
The practice of students in higher or vocational education pursuing studies in another country for defined periods of time.
Cooperative arrangements between educational institutions and private enterprise.
The study and practice of managing the resources, tasks and communications involved in running a school.
Mutual recognition of certificates and other documents confirming completion of vocational training.
A collection of lessons, assessments, and other academic content that's taught in a school, program, or class by a teacher.

Food security exists when all people have, at all times, physical, social and economic access to sufficient, safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary energy requirements and food preferences for an active and healthy life.

Claims made by food business operators when they want to highlight the particular beneficial effects of their products, in relation to nutrition, on the product label or in its advertising.  These apply to nutrition claims (such as "low fat", "high fibre").

Substances added intentionally to foodstuffs to perform certain technological functions, for example to colour, to sweeten or to help preserve foods. In the European Union all food additives are identified by an E number. The most common additives to appear on food labels are antioxidants (to prevent deterioration caused by oxidation), colours, emulsifiers, stabilisers, gelling agents and thickeners, preservatives and sweeteners.
Hygiene of food at all stages of the production process, from the primary production stage (mainly farming, hunting or fishing) to the final consumer.
A disease caused by consuming food or drinking water contaminated by pathogenic (disease-causing) micro-organisms such as bacteria and their toxins, viruses and parasites.

Concentrated sources of nutrients or other substances with a nutritional or physiological effect, whose purpose is to supplement the normal diet. Food supplements are marketed 'in dose' form, for example as pills, tablets, capsules or liquids in measured doses etc.
Violation of food law, which is committed intentionally to pursue an economic or financial gain through consumer deception.
Type of food that does not have a significant history of consumption or is produced by a method that has not previously been used for food.

Food contact materials (FCMs) are all materials that come into contact with food including packaging kitchenware and tableware and the materials used in professional food manufacturing, preparation, storage and distribution. It may also include articles which may foreseeably come into contact with food.

Claims used by food business operators when they want to highlight the particular beneficial effects of their products, in relation to health on the product label or in its advertising.  These are claims such as "Vitamin D is needed for the normal growth and development of bone in children".

Restrictive measures (sanctions) are an essential tool in the EU’s common foreign and security policy (CFSP), through which the EU can intervene where necessary to prevent conflict or respond to emerging or current crises. 
While EU sanctions inherently have an effect in non-EU countries, as they are a foreign policy tool, the measures apply only within EU jurisdiction.

synonyms: complaint about failure to take action
declaration of an EC failure to fulfil an obligation
declaration of an EC failure to take action

definition: Common foundation of rights and obligations which binds together the Member States of the European Union.
Normal procedure for adopting EU legislative acts, whereby the European Parliament and the Council, acting jointly, adopt a regulation, directive or decision on a proposal from the Commission.

The rules laid down in Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 defining how the Commission exercises the implementing powers conferred on it by the legislative authority (the European Parliament and the Council), with the help of committees which it chairs, comprising representatives of the Member States.
Negotiations held between the governments of the Member States with a view to amending the Treaties.

Opinions are non-binding legal acts adopted by the European institutions which do not bind those to whom they are addressed. It can be issued by the main EU institutions (Commission, Council, Parliament), the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee. Use with name of relevant institution.
An instrument that allows the the European Commission to make a statement in a non-binding fashion.
A discipline that studies the production, distribution, and consumption of forest products and services.
Illegal logging takes place when timber is harvested, transported, bought or sold in violation of national laws.
AMR is the ability of microorganisms (e.g. bacteria, viruses or parasites, such as the malaria parasite) to resist antimicrobial treatments, especially antibiotics.

synonyms: degenerative disease of the nervous system

definition: Infectious disease of animals which can be transmitted to humans.
A chronic illness is an illness continuing or occurring again and again for a long time.
Intensive outbreaks or periods of unusually high incidence of disease in a community or area.
Infection occurring in a patient during the process of care in a hospital.
A disease affecting a small patient population (defined in Europe as less than 1 in 2,000 citizens) for which it is not commercially viable to develop treatments.
An outbreak of a disease that occurs over a wide geographic area (such as multiple countries or continents) and typically affects a significant proportion of the population.
Proof of vaccination status.
Systems to identify, assess and communicate current and emerging threats to human health posed by infectious diseases.

A substance or combination of substances that is intended to treat, prevent or diagnose a disease, or to restore, correct or modify physiological functions by exerting a pharmacological, immunological or metabolic action.  For subject matter related to the regulation of medications, use pharmaceutical product.

A network of laboratories throughout the European Union that aims to ensure high-quality, uniform testing in the EU and support the European Commission's risk management and risk assessment activities in the area of animal health, food safety, public health and zootechnics.

The science and practice of protecting and improving the health of a community, as by preventive medicine, health education, control of communicable diseases, application of sanitary measures, and monitoring of environmental hazards.
The system used to keep healthy standards in a place where people live, especially by removing waste products and garbage safely.
A state of physical, mental, and social well-being in all matters relating to the reproductive system.
Absence of preventable harm to a patient during the process of health care.
Clinical trials are scientifically controlled studies undertaken in humans to establish or confirm the safety and effectiveness of investigational medicinal products (IMPs).

National competent authorities are organisations that have the legally delegated or invested authority, or power to perform a designated function, normally monitoring compliance with the national statutes and regulations.   Member States have an obligation to designate competent authorities under most of EU directives and regulations and to notify them to the European Commission.
Blood, tissues, cells and organs used in a variety of medical therapies.

A medical model using characterisation of individuals’ phenotypes and genotypes (e.g. molecular profiling, medical imaging, lifestyle data) for tailoring the right therapeutic strategy for the right person at the right time, and/or to determine the predisposition to disease and/or to deliver timely and targeted prevention.
Use of information and communication technologies for health and well-being.

The combination of all measures to reduce the risk of introduction and the spread of diseases in a herd, a region or a country.  Also defined as those actions designed to counter biological threats, reduce risks, and prepare for, respond to, and recover from bioincidents.

A health technology is the application of organized knowledge and skills in the form of devices, medicines, vaccines, procedures and systems developed to solve a health problem and improve quality of lives.

Health technology assessment (HTA) refers to the the systematic evaluation of properties, effects, and/or impacts of health technology. It is a multidisciplinary process to evaluate the social, economic, organizational and ethical issues of a health intervention or health technology. The main purpose of conducting an assessment is to inform a policy decision making.
Coordination among European countries to strengthen crisis preparedness and management of cross-border health threats.

An area in which the host EU Member State, the European Commission, relevant EU agencies and participating EU Member States cooperate, with the aim of managing an existing or potential disproportionate migratory challenge characterised by a significant increase in the number of migrants arriving at the external EU border.
The movement of people over some distance and from one "usual place of residence" to another.
In the global context , the act of arriving in a State with the intention to remain for a period exceeding one year.

A migratory movement in which an element of coercion exists, including threats to life and livelihood, whether arising from natural or man-made causes (e.g. movements of refugees and internally displaced persons as well as people displaced by natural or environmental disasters, chemical or nuclear disasters, famine, or development projects).
Migratory movement refers to the number of international migrants (a) arriving in a country or (b) departing from a country over a specific period.
A child under 18 years of age who is outside their country of origin and separated from both parents or their previous legal / customary primary caregiver.
Migration mainly for economic reasons or in order to seek material improvements to livelihood.
Relocation and integration of people (refugees, internally displaced persons, etc.) into another geographical area and environment, usually in a third country.
Administrative reform is a political process designed to adjust the relationships between a bureaucracy and other elements in a society, or within the bureaucracy itself.
Information dissemination is the means by which facts are distributed to the public at large.

related.prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

definition: A service which is provided by government to people living within its jurisdiction, either directly (through the public sector) or by financing private provision of services.
An administrative body for a  geographic area below the level of a national or central government.
Representatives of regional and municipal governments.
Local administration such as city governments.
Coordinated activity to direct and control an organisation with regard to risk.
Process by which governments or organisations translate their political vision into programmes and actions as a basis for delivering results and for making decisions.
Process whereby public authorities acquire works, supplies or services by one or more contracting authorities from economic operators chosen by those contracting authorities.
Process whereby public authorities seek to procure goods, services and works with a reduced environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
Use of electronic communications by public sector organisations when buying supplies and services or tendering public works.
Policy analysis refers to both the process of assessing policies or programs, and the product of that analysis.
The set of rules, procedures and institutions introduced by government for the express purpose of developing, administering and reviewing regulation.
Resilience is the ability of an individual, a community or a country to cope, adapt and quickly recover from stress and shocks caused by a disaster, violence or conflict.

The term preparedness refers to the ability of governments, professional response organisations, communities and individuals to anticipate and respond effectively to the impact of likely, imminent or current hazards, events or conditions. This concept covers both preparedness in terms of health emergencies within and external to the EU and other kinds of hazardous situations and disasters in the EU and globally.
An organization with culture or humanities as its primary mission and purpose.

Cultural heritage includes artefacts, monuments, a group of buildings and sites, museums that have a diversity of values including symbolic, historic, artistic, aesthetic, ethnological or anthropological, scientific and social significance. It includes tangible heritage (movable, immobile and underwater), intangible cultural heritage (ICH) embedded into cultural, and natural heritage artefacts, sites or monuments.
An artistic or architectural work, or other artifact of cultural significance.
The customs, language, arts, social institutions, and achievements of a particular nation, people, or other social group.
The various branches of creative activity, such as painting, music, literature, and dance.
A condition in which minority groups participate fully in the dominant society, yet maintain their cultural differences
Jewish heritage refers to everything that touches upon Jewish life, culture, art, ritual, history and literature, everything that touches upon Jewish space and Jewish time.
Type of award in the field of culture.
Activities and policies to honor the memory of Holocaust victims and encourage the development of educational programs about Holocaust history to help prevent future acts of genocide.
Acquiring new skills to start a completely different career. Not to be confused with updating of skills.
Writing skills include all the knowledge and abilities related to expressing ideas through the written word.
Skills combining knowledge and understanding with practice in language use, generally consisting of listening, speaking, reading and writing.
synonyms: Common European Framework of Reference for Languages

definition: A combination of financial awareness, knowledge, skills, attitudes and behaviours necessary to make sound financial decisions and ultimately achieve individual financial well-being.
The fundamental conditions of service and the basic rights, duties and obligations of employees.

related.prefLabel: discrimination on the basis of nationality

definition: Occupations requiring special training in the arts or sciences, such as lawyers, notaries, engineers, architects, doctors, and accountants.
A person's capacity to gain initial employment, maintain employment, and obtain new employment if required.

synonyms: declaration of a conflict of interest
declaration of a conflict of interests

definition: A means of making a living. It encompasses people's capabilities, assets, income and activities required to secure the necessities of life.
A strategic and systematic process through which labour market actors identify and prepare to meet future skills needs, thus helping to avoid potential gaps between skills demand and supply.

synonyms: balance between work and private life
reconciliation of personal and working life

definition: The aspects of economics concerned with the supply and demand for labour.

Obligation of employers to provide all job-seekers information on the pay range of positions they apply for and to provide employees with access to sex-disaggregated data to see whether their company pays men and women equally for the same work.
Discussions, consultations, negotiations and joint actions involving organisations representing the social partners – employers and workers.
Procedure to define the energy consumption and to identify energy saving opportunities for a building/group of buildings/process/system.
The trade or traffic of energy sources treated as a commodity (such as fossil fuel, electricity, or solar radiation).
Renewable energy available from seas and oceans.
Fundamental structural change in an energy system at national or global level.
Labels providing clear and simple indications of a product's energy efficiency intended to be a key driver for helping consumers choose products which are more energy efficient.
Measures the extent to which the ecological demand of human economies stays within or exceeds the capacity of the biosphere to supply goods and services.

Policy on air quality which develops and implements appropriate instruments to improve air quality. The main instruments are a series of Directives setting ambient air quality standards to provide protection from excessive pollution concentrations, based on the latest research on the health effects of air pollution.
Environmental issues are defined as problems with the planet's systems (air, water, soil, etc.).

A substance or a mixture fulfilling the criteria's relating to physical, health or environmental hazards as defined by the Regulation (EC) No 1272/2008 (regulation on the Classification, Labelling and Packaging of substances and mixtures).
Substances in our environment, food and consumer products that can disrupt endocrine systems and wildlife and result in adverse health effects.
A family of powerful man-made greenhouse gases used in a range of industrial applications.

Restoration is a process to support the recovery of degraded, damaged or destroyed ecosystems and bring more nature and biodiversity back everywhere, from agricultural and forest land to marine environment and urban spaces.

Actions to protect, sustainably manage, and restore natural or modified ecosystems, that address societal challenges effectively and adaptively, simultaneously providing human well-being and biodiversity benefits.

The sum of living and dead matter in soil and includes plant residues and microorganisms. Soil is one of the principal substrata of life on Earth, serving as a reservoir of water and nutrients, as a medium for the filtration and breakdown of injurious wastes, and as a participant in the cycling of carbon and other elements through the global ecosystem.

A generic term for non-renewable energy sources such as coal, coal products, natural gas, derived gas, crude oil, petroleum products and non-renewable wastes. These fuels originate from plants and animals that existed in the geological past. Fossil fuels can be also made by industrial processes from other fossil fuels (for example in the oil refinery, crude oil is transformed into motor gasoline).
Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is natural gas, predominantly methane, converted to liquid form for ease of storage or transport.
Unconventional hydrocarbons are sources of oil and gas which require additional or “unconventional” extraction methods which are not normally necessary in traditional oil and gas extraction.
Natural gas from shale formations.

The process of removing salts or other minerals and contaminants from seawater, brackish water, and wastewater effluent to obtain fresh water for human consumption and for domestic/industrial utilization.
Applies to the prevention of environmental risks.

synonyms: Implementation and Enforcement of Environmental Law

definition: Species that are not native to a particular ecosystem and whose introduction and spread cause, or are likely to cause, socio-cultural, economic or environmental harm or harm to human health.

Ecosystem services are the many and varied benefits that humans freely gain from the natural environment and from properly-functioning ecosystems. Such ecosystems include, for example, agroecosystems, forest ecosystems, grassland ecosystems and aquatic ecosystems.

Green infrastructure is a strategically planned network of natural and semi-natural areas with other environmental features designed and managed to deliver a wide range of ecosystem services such as water purification, air quality, space for recreation and climate mitigation and adaptation.

narrower.prefLabel: Court of Justice of the European Union

synonyms: Conference of the Heads of State or Heads of Government

prefLabel: Court of Justice of the European Union
synonyms: Court of Justice of the European Communities
Court of Justice of the European Union (institution)
Court of Auditors of the European Communities
Court of Auditors of the European Union

definition: Established by the Treaties to exist alongside the institutions of the European Union.

narrower.prefLabel: High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy

prefLabel: High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy

synonyms: Committee of the Regions of the European Union

definition: The EPPO is an independent Union body with the authority to investigate and prosecute EU-fraud and other crimes affecting the Union's financial interests. It combines European and national law-enforcement efforts in a unified, seamless and efficient approach to counter EU-fraud.
Arrangements temporarily limiting the free movement of workers from New to Old EU Member states during a new state's assession to the Union.

synonyms: Instrument for Structural Policies for Pre-Accession

definition: Legal and political process whereby an EU Member state exercises its right under the Treaty on European Union to cease to be a member of the Union.
synonyms: right of withdrawal from the EU
right of withdrawal from the European Union
withdrawal of a Member State from the EU

definition: A country is deemed to be a candidate country when, having examined its application for EU membership, the EU Council formally recognises the country as candidate, thus granting the country candidate status.
Countries that have signed the treaty of accession obtain the status of 'acceding country' and are expected to become full member states on the date set out in the treaty.
Staff regulations of officials of the European Union and the conditions of employment of other servants of the European Union.
synonyms: staff regulations for officials of the European Union
European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation

definition: Established by the Treaties to exist alongside the institutions of the European Union.

narrower.prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union
synonyms: Office for Official Publications of the European Communities

broaderPrefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

synonyms: statistical office of the European Communities
statistical office of the European Union

definition: Committee responsible for issuing opinions on the implementing measures proposed by the Commission, operating in accordance with the advisory procedure laid down in Article 3 of the Comitology Decision.

synonyms: Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market
Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs)

definition: European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union.
synonyms: European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union
European Border and Coast Guard Agency

definition: Consultative body set up by EU institutions to provide them with advice and expertise composed of public and/or private sector members.
Experts assist in the evaluation of grant applications, projects and tenders, and to provide opinions and advice in specific cases.

related.prefLabel: High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy

definition: Policy which aims to safeguard the common values and fundamental interests of the Union and of its Member States and to preserve and strengthen peace.
synonyms: Common European Security and Defence Policy

definition: The geographical areas in the European Union defined as regions for the purposes of administering macro-regional development programmes.

Regions of the European Union bordering on the Atlantic coast that share common opportunities and challenges related to their maritime physical and socio-economic context, and for many to their relatively peripheral location.
Covers eight EU countries (Sweden, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland).

Covers nine EU Member States (Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia), three accession countries (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Serbia) and two neighbourhood countries (Moldova and Ukraine).
Covers four EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia) and four non-EU countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Serbia).

synonyms: EC participation in an international meeting
EC representation in an international organisation
the international role of the European Union

definition: International ocean governance is about managing and using the world's oceans and their resources in ways that keep our oceans healthy, productive, safe, secure and resilient using international law and organizations to manage marine resources sustainably.
Joint initiative launched in 2009 between the EU and its eastern European partners (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine).

The process of raising funds or capital for any kind of expenditure. It is the process of channeling various funds in the form of credit, loans, or invested capital to those economic entities that most need them or can put them to the most productive use.
Transportation insurance is a policy that offers coverage on the insured's property while it is in transit from one location to another via any necessary mode of transport.
Contribution EU funding makes to a programme.

An emerging alternative form of financing that connects those who can give, lend or invest money directly with those who need financing for a specific project. It usually refers to public online calls to contribute finance to specific projects.
Investment made from the EU's budget to support EU's priorities.
Investment in the social and economic development of  regions and cities.
Green investments focus on companies or projects committed to the conservation of natural resources, pollution reduction, or other environmentally-conscious business practices.
Sustainable finance is a work stream to support the European Green Deal channelling private investment to the transition to a climate-neutral economy.
A global tax system to reduce tax competition among countries and tax evasion by corporations.
Tax levied on digital economy firms.

Policy aimed at curbing aggressive tax planning by increasing scrutiny around the previously-unseen activities of all tax intermediaries such as tax planners and advisers and by automatic exchange of information on tax rulings will enable Member States to detect certain abusive tax practice.
A proportion of the TAC (total allowable catch) allocated to the Union, a EU Member State or a third country.
Fisheries control and enforcement aims to ensure the correct application of regulations regarding fisheries and to impose compliance with these rules where necessary.

Refers to fishing activities conducted by foreign vessels without permission in waters under the jurisdiction of another state, or which contravene its fisheries law and regulations in some other manner – for example, by disregarding fishing times or the existence of the state’s protected areas.
The CE marking indicates a product’s compliance with EU legislation and so enables the free movement of products within the European market.
Methodologies for the development of products or a set of techniques normally involving users as well as designers to be employed in creating new technologies.
Specific groups of chemicals, such as biocides, pesticides, pharmaceuticals or cosmetics, that are covered by their own legislation in the EU.
Substance identification is a process by which the identity of the substance is established.
A field in cultural policy giving audiences centrality in the thinking of cultural institutions.
The art or profession of visual communication that combines images, words, and ideas to convey information to an audience.

News industry of the mass media that focus on delivering news to the general public through print media (newspapers, newsmagazines), broadcast news (radio and television) and the Internet (online newspapers).

Materials with engineered properties created through the development of specialized processing and synthesis technology, including ceramics, high value-added metals, electronic materials, composites, polymers, and biomaterials.
The engineering and operation of machines that can autonomously or semi-autonomously perform physical tasks on behalf of a human.
A field in electronics that utilizes tiny, or micro, components to manufacture electronics.

Semiconductors, sometimes referred to as integrated circuits (ICs) or microchips, are made from pure elements, typically silicon or germanium, or compounds such as gallium arsenide.  Semiconductors are used extensively in electronic circuits. As its name implies, a semiconductor is a material that conducts current, but only partly.
Software that can be freely used, changed, and shared (in modified or unmodified form) by anyone.

RPA is an application of technology, governed by business logic and structured inputs, aimed at automating business processes. Using RPA tools, a company can configure software, or a “robot,” to capture and interpret applications for processing a transaction, manipulating data, triggering responses and communicating with other digital systems. RPA scenarios range from something as simple as generating an automatic response to an email to deploying thousands of bots, each programmed to automate jobs in an ERP system.
The manipulation of data to produce useful information.
Deep learning computational data model from artificial intelligence capable of pattern recognition and machine learning, based on the structure and functions of biological neural network.
A field of computer science, artificial intelligence, and linguistics concerned with the interactions between computers and human (natural) languages.

Automated process of selecting and analyzing large amounts of text or data resources for purposes such as searching, finding patterns, discovering relationships, semantic analysis and learning how content relates to ideas and needs in a way that can provide valuable information needed for studies, research, etc.

Machine learning (ML) is a type of artificial intelligence (AI) that allows software applications to become more accurate at predicting outcomes without being explicitly programmed to do so. Machine learning algorithms use historical data as input to predict new output values.
All techniques used to determine the physical and biological features of objects by measures carried out at a distance without material contact with the object concerned.
Technology making it possible to share information and record transactions between two parties in a verifiable and permanent way.
An NFT is an asset verified using blockchain technology, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership.
Internal telecommunications and computer-network system designed to be used exclusively within a particular organisation. The protocols and technologies used are based on Internet technology.
Storing, processing and use of data on remotely located computers accessed over the internet.
The word edge in this context means literal geographic distribution.  Edge computing optimizes Internet devices and web applications by bringing computing closer to the source of the data.
A technology that uses artificial intelligence, machine learning, and big data analysis to provide cognitive awareness to objects that were in the past considered inanimate.

Enabling technologies that allow the creation of integrated and self-regulating systems beyond firm- or industry boundaries.  CPS are integrations of computation, networking, and physical processes. Embedded computers and networks monitor and control the physical processes, with feedback loops where physical processes affect computations and vice versa.

A global infrastructure for the information society, enabling advanced services by interconnecting (physical and virtual) objects based on existing and evolving interoperable information and communications technologies.
Refers to computing systems with extremely high computational power.

Quantum computing is an area of computing focused on developing computer technology based on the principles of quantum theory, which explains the behavior of energy and material on the atomic and subatomic levels.
Mobile application development is the set of processes and procedures involved in writing software for small, wireless computing devices.

The adoption of digital technology to transform services or businesses, through replacing non-digital or manual processes with digital processes or replacing older digital technology with newer digital technology.
An artificial digital environment that completely replaces the real world.
Digital content refers to products such as videos, music, software or live sports streaming events.
A technology that superimposes a computer-generated image on a user's view of the real world, thus providing a composite view.
Any product, compound, medicine or therapeutic which is subject to regulation as a drug, medicine or controlled substance.

Any substance or combination of substances presented for treating or preventing disease in animals. According to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), veterinary products include vaccines, veterinary medicines such as antimicrobial agents, and diagnostic kits.

The achievement of proper operating conditions, prevention of accidents or mitigation of accident consequences, resulting in protection of workers, the public and the environment from undue radiation hazards.
Event occurring in a nuclear power plant or anywhere that radioactive materials are used, stored, or transported.
Prevention of and response to criminal or intentional unauthorized acts involving or directed at nuclear material.
Measures to verify that states do not use nuclear materials to develop weapons and respect their obligations under international non-proliferation treaties.
Energy which is non-pollutant, whether renewable or not.
Activities which involve travel away from one’s “habitual” place of residence, which have as their host or focus the marine environment and/or the coastal zone.
Sector that produces the goods and services required to protect citizens from insecurity.

Any fuel that is derived from biomass—that is, plant or algae material or animal waste. Since such feedstock material can be replenished readily, biofuel is considered to be a source of renewable energy, unlike fossil fuels such as petroleum, coal, and natural gas.

Comprises of providers of diagnostic, preventive, remedial, and therapeutic services such as doctors, nurses, hospitals and other private, public, and voluntary organizations. It also includes medical equipment and pharmaceutical manufacturers and health insurance firms.
Accounting, design, maintenance, printing, and supply of temporary personnel, etc., provided by specialized firms to other firms.
Process of social and economic change caused by the removal or reduction of industrial capacity or activity in a country or region, especially of heavy industry or manufacturing industry.

related.prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

definition: A society where a significant degree of activity focuses on the creation, distribution, use and reuse of information. This activity takes place by means information and communication technologies (ICTs).
The movement or transfer of information between servers across country borders.
A fifth generation of telecommunication systems.
A wireless networking protocol that allows devices to communicate.

Use by mobile telecommunications subscribers of a mobile telephone or other device to make or to receive calls or to send or receive SMS messages or packet switched data communications on a visited network (i.e. outside the territory covered by their own provider’s network).
Practice of preventing access to websites, applications and media based on user's geographical location.
Data science is the field of study that combines domain expertise, programming skills, and knowledge of mathematics and statistics to extract meaningful insights from data.
A service, which provides (serves) data/knowledge/information somehow.
The science and practice dealing with the effective collection, storage, retrieval, and use of information.

related.prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

definition: Data produced by public sector bodies of the Member States, including executive, legislative and judicial bodies.

Practice of publishing (raw) data in a way that is accessible, reusable, machine readable and licensed permissively. Can be generated by a wide range of parties, including public authorities, the semi-public sector, businesses and the public. S

related.prefLabel: Publications Office of the European Union

synonyms: appeal to the Court of Cassation

definition: Refers to all the occupational roles purposely oriented towards the administration and maintenance of a legal system.
Civil procedure means the rules, principles, and practices by which civil (non-criminal) disputes are resolved according to the law.
Electronic evidence refers to various types of data in electronic form that are relevant in investigating and prosecuting criminal offences.
EU law takes precedence over any provision of the law of Member States which is contrary to it.

The principle of proportionality regulates the exercise of powers by the European Union (EU). It seeks to set actions taken by EU institutions within specified bounds. Under this rule, the action of the EU must be limited to what is necessary to achieve the objectives of the Treaties.

Means that both the EU and its Member States may adopt legally binding acts in the area concerned.  However, the Member States can do so only where the EU has not exercised its competence or has explicitly ceased to do so.
Issues involving an aspect of EU law and an aspect of law in an EU country (national law).

Tribunals can be described as minor courts, that adjudicates disputes arising in special case.  Court refers to a part of legal system which are established to give their decisions on civil and criminal cases.
The language industry is the totality of professionals, companies and organisations involved in the development, production and marketing of language solutions.
The general movement, drift or direction of change in a viewpoint collectively and purportedly held by a significant number of people.

An open forum which is beyond the state and the market, where private citizens assemble in order to deliberate, problematise, criticise, debate, and (inter)act on equal terms with public authorities, in the context of constitutional democracy, having received knowledge and information by different associations and the media.
An orientation that characterizes the thinking of a group or nation.
Social movements and political parties organized around a range of political ideologies that support and seek to achieve social equality and egalitarianism, often in opposition to social hierarchy.
Adherence to a middle-of-the-road position, neither left nor right in politics.
A political tendency supporting conservative or traditional ideas and policies.

synonyms: verification of the regularity of an election

definition: Risk reduction includes prevention, preparedness, and part of the recovery process, and it gives particular emphasis to the reduction of vulnerability.
Includes any systematic response to an unexpected or dangerous occurrence. The goal of an emergency response procedure is to mitigate the impact of the event on people and the environment.
Whistleblowing is bringing into the open information on activities that have harmed or threaten the public interest.
Protection of systems, networks and assets whose continuous operation is deemed necessary to ensure the security of a State, its economy, and the public’s health and safety.

The security of equipment and technology that is placed or anchored on the ocean floor, including underwater sensors, power transfer systems for supplying power to underwater devices, submarine communication cables that carry telecommunications signals across stretches of ocean and sea, and equipment used for inspecting underwater infrastructure.
EU exchange of information system on dangerous products posing a risk to health and safety of consumers.
The resulting effects and interrelationships of human population concentrations, the built environment, and the biophysical environment.

The fundamental facilities serving a country, city, or area, as transportation and communication systems, power plants, and roads and a system through which urban services, of various kinds, are provided.

A smart city is a place where the traditional networks and services are made more efficient with the use of digital and telecommunication technologies, for the benefit of its inhabitants and businesses.

The New European Bauhaus is an environmental, economic and cultural project, aiming to combine design, sustainability, accessibility, affordability and investment in order to help deliver the European Green Deal.
European policy destinated to EU member states and third countries located in a defined geographical area, with the aim to achieve a better economic, social and territorial cohesion.

Impact assessments examine whether there is a need for EU action and analyse the possible impacts of available solutions. These are carried out during the preparation phase, before the Commission finalises a proposal for a new law. They provide evidence to inform and support the decision-making process.
Process in which companies, public research institutions, financial institutions interact through the exchange of skills, knowledge and ideas for creating new products.
Intangible property rights (as ownership of a trademark or patent) connected with agriculture, commerce, and industry.

The manufacture, import, export, distribution, and sale of consumer goods that are not genuine but are designed and branded to look identical to the authentic products in order to deceive consumers into believing that they are authentic.
European Union Trademark recognised and protected in all the Member States of the EU and registered with the European Union Intellectual Property Office (EUIPO).
A prize or other mark of recognition given in honor of an achievement in education or research.

Research ethics addresses the application of ethical principles or values to various issues and fields of research, including: ethical aspects of the design and conduct of research, the way human participants or animals within research projects are treated, whether research results may be misused for criminal purposes, and aspects of scientific misconduct.
Attitude of the researchers to conduct research according to appropriate ethical, legal and professional frameworks and standards
Evaluation methods are the criteria for evaluating the success of a programme or project.
Facilities, resources and services used by the science community to conduct research and foster innovation.
Scientific process based on cooperative work and new ways of knowledge distribution using digital technologies and new collaborative tools.
Participation of the citizens in the scientific research process in different possible ways: as observers, as funders, in identifying images or analysing data, or providing data themselve.

Geographical concentration of large and small companies, research laboratories and educational institutions, all working together in a specific region to develop synergies and cooperative efforts on innovative joint projects aimed at specific markets”.

EU Missions are a coordinated effort by the Commission to pool the necessary resources in terms of funding programmes, policies and regulations, as well as other activities.  Missions support research to deliver on the Commission's main priorities and to find responses to some of the greatest challenges.  Each mission operates as a portfolio of actions.

A process that enables the socioeconomic use of humanistic, scientific and technical knowledge by means of interaction with third parties in contracted research activities or collaborations, consulting and technical services, in the protection of the research results, licenses, rights of use, and in the creation of spin-offs, including technology transfer.
Information system for use in decision-making in several domains, most of which relate to the human use of the physical environment.
The gathering of information about planet Earth’s physical, chemical and biological systems.
Study of the chemical structures and processes of biological phenomena at the molecular level.

Genomics is the study of the full genetic complement of an organism (the genome). It employs recombinant DNA, DNA sequencing methods, and bioinformatics to sequence, assemble, and analyse the structure and function of genomes.

Computational biology and bioinformatics is an interdisciplinary field that develops and applies computational methods to analyse large collections of biological data, such as genetic sequences, cell populations or protein samples, to make new predictions or discover new biology. The computational methods used include analytical methods, mathematical modelling and simulation.
The study of the social, psychological and biological aspects of ageing.
The exercise of the profession of medicine.
Brain research studies the structure and function of human brains and the nervous system.
Research on the connections between the underlying structure of a material, its properties, its processing methods and its performance in applications.
Research in the field of transportation engineering and planning.
The science and technology of light. Photonics deals with generating, guiding, manipulating, amplifying and detecting light.

Research to enhance security and industrial performance by developing technologies and tools that meet needs of those dealing with threats such as terrorism, cybercrime, weapons and human trafficking, as well as natural disasters.

Any set of productive techniques which offers a significant improvement (whether measured in terms of increased output or savings in costs) over the established technology for a given process in a specific historical context.
Foresight is the disciplined exploration of alternative futures.
Monitoring of the implementation of the investigative function of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).

A binding legislative act that must be applied in its entirety across the EU.  In non-EU context, regulation should be considered as an act of general significance issued by an authority other than parliament.

synonyms: equal rights of men and women
protection of those charged with crimes

definition: The principle of equal treatment establishes that all people – and in the context of the workplace, all workers – have the right to receive the same treatment and not to be discriminated against on the basis of criteria such as age, disability, nationality, race and religion.

Political rights refer to an individual's ability to participate in the civil and political life of the society and state without fear of discrimination or repression, and is tied closely to citizenship status.
Policies and measures to strengthen the safety of journalists and other media professionals.

narrower.prefLabel: discrimination on the basis of nationality
discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation

prefLabel: discrimination on the basis of nationality
discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation

definition: Any kind of communication in speech, writing or behaviour that attacks or uses pejorative or discriminatory language with reference to a person or a group based on their religion, ethnicity, nationality, race, colour, descent, gender or other identity factor.
A written or spoken agreement, especially one concerning employment, sales, or tenancy, that is intended to be enforceable by law.
an individual human being as distinct from a corporate body or entity.
Responsibility that someone has for their actions, for example the responsibility to pay another person for harm or damage that is a result of these actions.
Ownership is the state or fact of legal possession and control over property, which may be any asset, tangible or intangible.
Delivery of digital media content usually through the Internet.

A form of favouritism based on acquaintances and familiar relationships whereby someone in an official position exploits his or her power and authority to provide a job or favour to a family member or friend, even though he or she may not be qualified or deserving.
parental responsibility, especially as allocated to one of two divorcing parents.

related.prefLabel: discrimination on the basis of nationality

definition: Any authorisation issued by the authorities of an EU Member State allowing a non-EU national to stay legally in its territory, in accordance with the provisions of Regulation (EU) No 265/2010 (Long Stay Visa Regulation).

Someone who is unable or unwilling to return to their country of origin owing to a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion.
Third country national or a stateless person who has made an application for asylum in respect of which a final decision has not yet been taken.

Temporary protection is an exceptional measure to provide immediate and temporary protection to displaced persons from non-EU countries and those unable to return to their country of origin.  It applies when there is a risk that the standard asylum system is struggling to cope with demand stemming from a mass influx risking a negative impact on the processing of claims.
Agreement aimed at the gradual abolition of controls on persons at the internal frontiers of the EU.

synonyms: internal border of the European Union
external borders of the European Union
